text:

`helm install validator <oci://ghcr.io/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/helm/splice-validator> -n validator --version ${CHART_VERSION} -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/validator-values.yaml -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-validator-values.yaml --wait`
for a few hours already, please advise thanks.

text:
Yea I would like to know why connect timeout.

> $ curl <https://scan.sv-1.dev.global.canton.network.sync.global/api/scan/version>
> {“version”:“0.3.21",“commit_ts”:“2025-04-17T08:39:03Z”}
> $ kubectl exec -it validator-app-8785f5478-87q8z -n validator -- curl <https://scan.sv-1.dev.global.canton.network.sync.global/api/scan/version>
> Defaulted container “validator-app” out of: validator-app, validator-init (init)
> curl: (28) Failed to connect to <http://scan.sv-1.dev|scan.sv-1.dev>.global.canton.network.sync.global port 443 after 258548 ms: Connection timed out
No idea why, maybe kubernetes block or what.

I’m using GCP VM + Kubernetes service.

text:
The VM that run validator node.

Oh wait do SVs need to whitelist Kubernetes IP instead of VM IP? Sorry I’m new to Kubernetes, worked with Docker before all working smoothly.

elements.text:
The VM that run validator node.

Oh wait do SVs need to whitelist Kubernetes IP instead of VM IP? Sorry I’m new to Kubernetes, worked with Docker before all working smoothly.

text: I think everything make sense to me now. GCP Kubernetes is different from VM instance, Kubernetes can be treat as a standalone engine with its own IP, no need rely on VM instance. Thanks <@U01DARYACCT> and <@U06HUQ2M0FP> for giving tips!:pray:

elements.text: I think everything make sense to me now. GCP Kubernetes is different from VM instance, Kubernetes can be treat as a standalone engine with its own IP, no need rely on VM instance. Thanks
